choices.text: Growth shows cephalocaudal & distal to proximal progression
Weight loss of 7-10% in the first week of life is normal in a term child
Height of a child increases by up to 50% in the first 2 years of life from birth
Skeletal tissue shows a sigmoid growth pattern in childhood

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not correct regarding growth of a child?
questions.solution:
Let us discuss individual options

  • Option A is correct. Growth of a child is cephalocaudal & distal to proximal.
  • Option B is correct. A child can lose upto 7-10% of birth weight in the 1st week of life. Birth weight is regained by day 10. Beyond 10th day, a child gains 20-40 gm/day of weight till 3 months of age.
  • Option C is incorrect. Height gain by 50% occurs by 1 yr of age, not 2 years. At birth, length is 50 cm and becomes 75 cm at 1 yr, so gain is 50% at 1 year of age.
  • Option D is correct. Skeletal tissue shows a sigmoid/S-shaped growth pattern.

questions.text: The height of a child is plotted over the years on a height for age chart, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The child has height for age just below 3rd centile, but is showing catch-up growth between 12-15 yr, indicating delayed puberty with catch up growth. Adult height has become normal, as seen in the graph. This is consistent with a diagnosis of Constitutional Delay in Growth.

questions.text: Most common skull suture affected in craniosynostosis is?
questions.solution:
Sagittal suture is most commonly affected, producing craniosynostosis.

  • Premature fusion of sagittal suture produces dolichocephalic skull or scaphocephalic skull.
  • These patients have increased AP diameter and reduced Biparietal diameter of the skull.
  • 80% cases are males.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to Emergency with complaints of severe pain abdomen which was colicky, tender mass, irritability and stools as shown below. What is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is pointing to a diagnosis of Intussusception.

  • Please note that the stools show a red currant jelly appearance.
  • According to Nelson 22nd Ed, USG Abdomen is a sensitive test & performed immediately in a patient with clinical suspicion of intussusception.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought for routine well-child examination. The patient is breast-fed, and his mother follows a vegan diet. The mother says she plans to breast-feed until the patient reaches six months of age, and then she will introduce him to solid foods that conform to her vegan diet. The new-born is at greatest risk for deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12, or cyanocobalamin, is mainly found in animal products, individuals who follow a strict vegan diet commonly have deficiency of this nutrient.

  • In breast-feeding mothers who follow a vegan diet, the breast milk supply is likely to reflect this deficiency.
  • Because the patient described is breast-fed and his mother follows a vegan diet, he is at greatest risk for deficiency of Vitamin B12.

questions.text: Breast milk contains non-digestible carbohydrates called Human milk oligosaccharides. What is the function of these in a child?
questions.solution:
Human Milk Oligosaccharides, HMOs are the third most abundant solid component in human milk, after lactose and lipids.

  • They are composed of complex carbohydrates, including sugars like galactose, glucose, fucose, N-acetylglucosamine, and sialic acid.
  • HMOs act as prebiotics, meaning they are not digested but instead provide fuel for the growth of beneficial gut bacteria. This helps establish a healthy gut microbiome, which is crucial for immune development and overall health.
  • Bifidus factor is a type of HMO.

questions.text: In a 28-week child with suspected RDS, what of the following occurs?
questions.solution:
RDS occurs due to deficiency of surfactant in alveoli.

  • Surfactant lining the alveoli enhances the aeration of gas-free lungs by reducing surface tension, thereby lowering the pressure required to open alveoli.
  • Air entry into the lungs displaces fluid, decreases hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary vasculature, and increases pulmonary blood flow.
  • In the absence of pulmonary surfactant, significantly increased alveolar surface tension leads to atelectasis, and the ability to attain an adequate FRC is impaired.
  • Alveolar atelectasis, hyaline membrane formation, and interstitial edema make the lungs less compliant in RDS, so greater pressure is required to expand the alveoli and small airways.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought with complaints of intermittent noisy breathing, which increases when the child is agitated and disappears when the child is calm. On examination, there was low-pitched, inspiratory stridor without any other positive finding. What is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution: The diagnosis is Laryngomalacia. All options are correct, except option C. Laryngoscopy is investigation of choice since it shows the typical "Omega Epiglottis".

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred therapy in a child with West Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Treatment Summary in West Syndrome

  • 1st line: High dose ACTH. If not available, give Prednisolone.
  • 2nd line: Vigabatrin
  • Exception- If patient has West Syndrome with Tuberous Sclerosis, DOC is Vigabatrin
  • Refractory cases- Respond to Ketogenic Diets or Topiramate.

questions.text: A neonate having hemodynamically significant PDA needs medical closure by Indomethacin. Which among the following will be a contraindication for medical therapy?
questions.solution:
Contraindications for Medical closure of PDA by indomethacin include:

  • Platelet count <50000/mm³ (<80000 as per other texts)
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Renal failure with serum creatinine> 1.8 mg/dl
  • Urine output below 1 ml/kg/hr
  • Suspected or definite NEC (Altered gastric aspirates or increased pre-feed aspirates is an early sign of NEC)
  • Unexplained bleeding from any site & History of intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice in a child aged 3 yr, detected to have grade 4 VUR, with 2 episodes of UTI in past 6 months?
questions.solution:
VUR is graded from Grade I-V using MCU.

  • Low grade-VUR is Grade I & II, while High-grade VUR is Grade III, IV or V.
  • For Low grade VUR, observation is recommended. However, if these patients have recurrent UTI or bowel bladder dysfunction, we start Antibiotics.
  • According to OP Ghai 10th Ed as well as Nelson, for VUR grades 3-5, primary therapy is Continuous Antibiotic Prophylaxis.
  • Surgery is done in VUR if there is breakthrough UTI despite antibiotic use.

questions.text: Highest mortality rates in childhood meningitis are observed with which of the following agents?
questions.solution: As per Nelson, the mortality rates in childhood meningitis beyond neonatal period is less than 10%. The highest mortality rates are observed for pneumococcal meningitis, followed by N meningitides & E coli. Among those who survive, 10-20% develop neurodevelopmental sequelae in childhood pyogenic meningitis.

questions.text: In Sickle Cell Anemia, which drug is used to decrease the incidence of painful vaso-occlusive crisis?
questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell anemia often suffer from painful vasocclusive crises owing to obstruction of microvasculature by the sickled shaped RBCs. Drugs useful to prevent such crises include

  • Hydroxyurea- Acts by increasing HbF and reduces the sickling as well as crises in such patients. It prevents acute chest syndrome, stroke and painful crises in sickle cell anemia. Dose used is 10-15 mg/kg/day as a single daily dose. However, monitor these children for complete blood counts.
  • L-Glutamine- The FDA has approved oral L-glutamine, used as an add on to hydroxyurea, for patients ≥5 yr. L-glutamine has been shown to reduce hospitalizations and sickle cell crisis.
  • Crizanlizumab and Voxelotor are the newer medications to reduce crisis, acting by inhibiting HbS polymerization.

questions.text: A 2.5-year-old child presents with high grade fever, barking cough and stridor while crying. Child accepts fluids normally. On examination respiratory rate is 34/ min and temperature of 102 F. Next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is mild croup, because child has fever, stridor and barking cough. As per Table given in OP Ghai 10th Ed, stridor only on cough or crying is mild croup while stridor at rest indicates moderate to severe croup.

  • Effectiveness of Oral Corticosteroids: Oral corticosteroids are effective in viral croup as they reduce laryngeal mucosa edema through their anti-inflammatory action. They are beneficial even in mild croup, reducing hospitalization, duration of hospitalization, and the need for additional interventions like epinephrine.
  • Indications for Nebulized Epinephrine: Nebulized epinephrine is indicated for moderate to severe croup, including cases with moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. It is not typically used for mild croup.
  • Antibiotics are not Indicated: Antibiotics are not typically indicated in croup as it is primarily caused by viral infections.

questions.text: A >48-hour neonate has still not passed meconium after birth. What is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
A water-soluble contrast enema is the investigation of choice in delayed passage of meconium since it is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

  • It can diagnose Hirschsprung disease, meconium ileus, atresias
  • Can also remove meconium plug in meconium plug syndrome and have therapeutic action.

questions.text: A newborn has been diagnosed with aniridia. Which of the following tests should be performed on this patient?
questions.solution:
Aniridia involves the whole eye and should not be thought of as an isolated iris defect. Iris tissue usually is present but is hypoplastic.

  • It usually occurs bilaterally and vision is severely impaired. Aniridia can either be a sporadic occurrence or can have an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. One-fifth of the patients with sporadic aniridia will develop Wilms tumour.
  • These patients will need surveillance with renal ultrasound every 4-6 months.
  • There is also an association between Wilms tumour, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and mental retardation (WAGR acronym).

questions.text: Which of the following is most common type of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF)?
questions.solution: Among these, Type C, where there is proximal esophageal atresia with distal TEF is most common.

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect with pulmonary arterial hypertension

questions.text: A young female presents with history of dyspnea on exertion. On examination, she has wide, fixed split S2, with ejection systolic murmur in left second intercostal space. Her ECG shows left axis deviation. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Wide fixed splitting S2, in association with ejection systolic murmur suggests the diagnosis of Atrial septal defect. Ideally with hypertrophy of the right side of the heart, right axis deviation should be present, but left axis deviation is seen in patients of ostium primum A.S.D.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was admitted with recurrent bloody stools, atopic dermatitis like rash and petechiae. On CBC, his TLC was normal and platelet count 20000/mm³. What is the next best step to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a male child presenting with a triad of

  1. Atopic dermatitis-like rash
  2. Recurrent bloody stools indicating recurrent infections
  3. Petechiae due to thrombocytopenia.
  • This is the classic triad seen in patients with Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome.
  • The disease occurs due to mutations in WASp gene mutations, present on Chromosome 11p22.23
  • Hence, patient needs to be screened for WASp gene expression.
